Another Filament roll holder. The "FilamenthalterInnen" are used to put into the filament rolls holes ( dia: 32mm else they have to be adjusted ).
The" nipples" have to be equipped with 8x22x7 ball bearings, secured with flat head M4 screws and washers.
You will need two for every roll. Depending on how many rolls you want to hang in at the same time you need 2 times
the "Filamenthalter Seite" and for every roll n>=2 another "Filamenthalter Mitte". For example I am using 2 rolls at the same time, placed 2 "Filamenthalter Seite" at the sides an one "Filamenthalter Mitte" in the middle. If you wanted to place 3 rolls you needed 2 "Filamenthalter Seite" for the sides and 2 "Filamenthalter Mitte" between the rolls. The holders can be attached directly to the wall, i prefer attaching them on a board, wich is placed at the wall. That makes it easier to level the things.
Make sure the distances between the "Filamenthalter" do not allow to much clearance, that would reduce the stability. To mount the rolls you just hang them into the "Filamenthalter". I printed with 3 perimeters, 0.2mm layer height and 35% infill PLA. Onces you've done all this you got a solid holder for as many rolls you need with very little friction and easiest exchange of filament rolls. It also requires little space. I am using this for a few month now and never had problems.

I very much enjoy retro gaming and retropie has made retro gaming so much easier. This is my attempt at building a Raspberry PI Zero into a real NES Controller. The nes controller is wired onto the gpio and I'm using the gamecon_gpio_rpi software for interface to the nes emulator.
I decided not to dremel the back part of the controller, but rather design and print a new one with proper pizero ports.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes: Nothing fancy or difficult about this print :)

Instructions (1) Print Back Cover
(2) Hot glue pizero into case
(3) Connect nes controller wiring to gpio
(4) Setup Software
(5) Play Games!

title: Vertex K8400 Ventilateur de pièce clipsable sans outils

description.text:
Voila un support pour ventilateur de pièce clipsable sans outils. Il est donc très facile de le mettre ou non en fonction du type de filament utilisé, ABS ou PLA.
Il dirige également le flux d'air au plus près de la pièce. La prochaine étape est de créer un autre support pour accrocher l'ensemble quelque part lorsque l'on ne veut pas s'en servir. Affaire a suivre. Si un modèle pour la version 2 têtes d'impression vous intéresse, c'est par ici : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1213663

Rien à prévoir au niveau quincaillerie, on réutilise l'existant.
Il faut juste tarauder les trous de fixation du ventilateur en M3 Aucun paramètres a changer, ça passe avec les réglages d'origine sur les 3 axes.

The kit did not include very good parts and still has some design flaws like toolson mentions.
I made this remix to improve quality of the printer.
Since the quality was not that high on initial prints and the outer walls of the nut traps and screw holes were full of gaps I decided to add a little material around them.
The v4 frame as plenty of room, so it does not interfere with the axis movement.
I also added some little supports to the gap for the belt because my printer did not cope well with bridges yet.
This remix is really just when you have a printer that does not cope well with slim walls.

The Idea
I don't like the spirit level on a bow sight. It's important to keep the bow perpendicular to the ground. However, keeping your eye focus on the tiny bubble 20inches away, then change your focus to the target 20 yards downrange is such a tedious task. And it takes time. The Designs
  • Let's scrub the spirit level.
  • I use a hinge to suspend the ring on its axis. Now it's kinda like a pendulum. If you camber your bow, the sight will lean with the bow.
  • The two "wings", I call stopper, prevent the ring from going too far out or swinging uncontrollably (if you draw your bow from a weird position). They also give a clearer peep picture of how much you are leaning your bow. Also mind that strong cross wind can blow away your ring. If you think so, make yourself a full circle stopper. I'm lazy man.
    • A Few Thoughts
  • This is somewhat a "one stone two birds" kinda thing. The sight tells you your bow is leaning but you can actually just ignore this information and take the shot. The ring-and-pin will always stay perpendicular to the ground, which is exactly how your arrow will fall - perpendicular to the ground. Get it ? :P Gravity don't lie.
  • I made a mistake and built the measurements around M3 bolts. Parts turned out way smaller than expected. Should've done with M4. But hey it's only my second 3DP project. Maybe it'd be fine if it was milled out of aluminium?
  • If I had some miniature bearing to use for the hinge, the swinging motion would be much smoother. Right now the parts I printed with my reprap feels really flimsy.
    • Extras
    I first wanted to make a quick prototype with just a Z axis adapter to my Trophy Ridge knock off. But I ended up making the entire rig with adjustable elevation and windage scale. Enjoy!

It holds 7 pens / pencils. I intended to put my own name on it, hence the 'underline' going across the front. For some reason, my OpenScad program omits the text when I render. Please comment about it if you know the answer to THAT issue. Eventually, I should be able to have a customizer where people can put the text of their preference. It's supposed to have a classy appearance, so please put 7 NICE pens in there, not just any pens! Just kidding, but seriously.
The underline gradually comes out from the side of the stand. This means that you will not need any support material to print it. I designed it that way to help support any letters to be printed there. Your letters can now rely on that underline to have a print that needs no support (think about it- without the underline, the letters have no support). Still, letters like 'g' and 'y' that hang under the underline might suffer from no support.
The openscad script was written on a linux machine, so it uses the standard unix-style return lines which Microsoft notepad doesn't understand. If you open it on windows with notepad, it will look horrible. Open the openscad script with a real editor like jedit, notepad++, etc.

A while ago I wrote a program to read and solve the Professor version (5x5x5) of the Rubik's cube.
I then decided to build a robot to actually do the reading and the moving... My first prototype was built in plywood, but then I decided I wanted to build something that was less prone to defects , so I got my first Makerbot, redesigned most of the components, and started printing! This is an ongoing project, and I still have my plywood components working, waiting to be replaced by their ABS counterparts. The electronics is based on an Arduino that reads the input from an external PC where the Solver software runs; it then drives the 12 servos that manipulate the Cube.

MachineEnsemble.scad is just meant to show how the 6 internal cages work together, and is based on the other printable files. By turning on automation on the 'pos' variable, it shows how the cube is manipulated.
Two of the main components (Cage and IntTransmission) are too long/big to be printed in one piece on my Makerbot, so I had to devise a way to break them up. That's why I have "CageTop", "OnePiece", and "CageBottom" pieces.
I've tried several existing thread 'things', but I ended up designing this very simple one, which is easier to print.
I have not (yet) included the outer shell of the machine (a 780x780x780 plywood box) or the internal cage holders (mostly plywood, with printed ABS bearings and bearing holders).
Nov-13:After a forced stop in printing (apparently my TOM's motherboard and extruder controller were fried!), I restarted by tweaking print parameter for the 3 components of the main cage (CageTop, OnePiece, CageBottom). The main issue wasthe curling upwards of the 4 corners; after several tries, mainly tweaking infill% and plaftorm temp, I got very good results with 20% and 135, respectively. All other parameters I found work best at their default values (0.35mm layer height and 225C extruder temp, 30 feedrate).I had to get rid of the Kapton belt on my ABP to get more reliable results.
I crafted this....

Here are all my improvements i´ve done on my K8200 Printer.
i would like to share with you. All improvements costs are lower than 100 € Enclosure ist made out of 3 IKEA Lack tables 5,99€ each.
The k8200 or 3drag will fit perfectly in it. The enclosure is updatet with some IKEA Led strips to light the printer up. The electrical box is made out of an Electrical Box 200 x 150 x110
2x 90 mm fan´s and some switches / emergency switch.
i had the problem that the printer disconnects sometimes or the printer stops currently.
Since i had the extra cooling and the box . This problem never appeared again.
One fan blows air into the case, the other one blows the "hot" air out. Inside the electrical box i used crimp contacts to connect the original k8200 cables to H07 0,75mm2 cable. This one has lower resistance and looks better. And it increases the resistance against mechanical burden. The Solid state Relais DC DC 8€ each i use for the heater cartridge (work in progress ) and the heatbed. I upgraded the original heatbed with a 24V power supply, so it can reach up to 110C°
I isolated the metal underground with a silicone baking matt for 5€ the topside is upgraded with a glass plate. The solid state relais switches on / off the power . The temperature is still switchable with the board like before. Before i start to print i clean the glass plate with 100% alcohol. So it is fat free and your prints will stick on it like hell. I print PLA with 60C° heatbed temperature. ABS is not tested. The wobbling Z Axis is one problem too. i printed out a new Z motor holder and upgrded the motor with a flex coupler. a Tr 8 x 1,5 spindle and a Tr 8 x1,5 Nut. The print results are very good now. The printer is still a work in progress project an i will update it soon.

Did you ever want to have rainbow prints ?
This Thing adds a knob to your printer where you can change the colormix ration of your
printer right during printing. So if you use yellow and blue filament, you can select to use
any green color during print, and you can change the ratio instantiously at any Z level. To realize this you need
  • Arduino Ramps based printer
  • Source code and Arduino Compiler in place
  • Chimera dual color nozzle
  • Dual extruder setup
  • 10K Potentiometer
  • 3 wired cable and 3pin connector
    • To implement
  • Patch the Marlin source code with the changes given
  • Connect the potentiometer to the pin connector and attach it to AUX-1
    such, that
    A - 5V (AUX1)
    MID - A57 (AUX1)
    B - GND(AUX1)
    • What the patch does: It reads the setting from the potentiometer and does balance
    the extruder counts given in the program to both extruders See pictures for result.(i used white and black to create a Halloween pacman ghost)

author: PascalThibault

description.text:
Derby County FC cookie cutter
COYR!

(This was designed for the Making Merry contest)
For me, the Making Merry contest and 3-D printing in general,are all about enjoying the machines. Regardless of whether there is a $2000 or a $400 machine, everyone can get together and talk about how to improve their 3-D printer as well as show off what they as an individual can give back to the community. This sharing of open source 3-D printers and models has what allowed the industry to grow as big as it is today. So this is what I am giving to the world, a 5.5:1 scale of the Ultimaker 2. I made this not only because it is the prize of the contest, but because It is a beautiful machine and because I saw it as a challenge to model. It prints as three separate parts, the body of the printer, the extrude with the x and y axes, and the front panel with the ultimaker logo. Slide the front x-axis rod into the back of the utlimaker panel(so that the extruder nozzle is on the left side), then snap all parts into place and slide the logo down into place.

comments.text: Now, scale it in Z (mostly) and you get an cool pencil holder :-)

description.text:
This is attempt to make dancing snowman parametric. So far i've produced just basic shape - things like buttons, hands ,face features and hat are on TODO list. parameters :
snowball_scale_ratio=0.5; // overall scale of snowballs and figurine in general.
0.5 is used mainly for testing and produces very tiny figurine.
this is main thing you want to adjust :) features_scale_ratio=1; // so far unused. will be used to adjust scale of features like nose, buttons, etc. separately. wall_thickness=0.7; // thickness of all walls. setting this to extrusion width is minimum but may cause problems on top of snowballs, etc. usually twice the extrusion width is ok. tolerance=0.8; // tolerance for ball joint. decrease for tighter fit, increase if you get your joint fused after print.

title: Simple bowden extruder for geared Nema 17

description.text:
Just another MK8 bowden extruder, this one is for a geared Nema17 stepper motor with the ratio 5.18:1. It was designed for a Rostock Mini Pro with minimal parts to print. Parlist:
1 x Nema17 geared stepper
1 x MK8 drive gear
3 x M3 x 23mm screws
1 x M4 x 12mm screw
1 x Ball bearing 11mm x 4mm x 4mm
1 x Bowden tube fitting M5
1 x Strong spring ~ 25-30mm x 7mm (force at the bearing ~60N with my setup, needs to be reduced a bit) Also included, a fixture to mount it at the smooth rods of a Rostock Mini if used in this combination, further M3 screws required.

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

35%

Depending on the used printer, the holes must be drilled to match the screws (I had to). Setup is quite easy:
  • Printing both parts
  • Installing the bowden fitting at the extruder block
  • Installing the bearing with the M4 screw
  • Putting the lever over the axis of the block
  • Mounting the extruder to the Nema17 motor by three M3 screws
  • Insert the spring, pocket is open to easily exchange the spring in order to find the right setup

description.text: Sans professional rite of passage, the Reverse Engineer's Ring is a variation of a Canadian engineering tradition - the Iron Ring. The Reverse Engineer's Ring is to serve as a reminder that you don't have to be building bridges or parking structures to have the potential to accidentally ruin somebody's day or somebody's life with your creations. Out of respect for the original tradition, the design of the ring is coarser in appearance (six facets top and bottom instead of twelve). The ring should be worn on the little finger of your dominant hand, such that when you draw or write, the flat edges rub against the page.

This ring was created using Blender's bolt generator plugin, and some trial and error.  I printed a few different versions in plastic first with one of my Repraps, so I could wear the ring around for a while to debug it before printing it in "stainless" steel via an online printing service.  
I encourage you to follow this method, as it will result in something relatively unique.  
For those interested, the file provided here (if I uploaded the right thing) has an inner diameter of approximately 17mm.

comments.text: This was exactly what I was looking for, thx!

comments.text: I love this!  I only just learned of the Engineer's Ring tradition after I saw this post.  I can't wait to get my real one in 4 years!  Would it be disrespectful of the tradition to wear this one while I'm a student?

This a normal 3x3 Rubik's Cube in the shape of a toroid. In this puzzle you do not need stickers on the puzzle because you can match the shape of the pieces together instead of matching the colors.
This puzzle is relatively easy to print requiring little support material and not requiring any additional hardware.

These are the plastic parts needed to build a automatic pluviometer. When used with a Yocto-Knob this thing will allow to find out if the weather is as bad you think it is.

These are plastic parts needed to build an USB pluviometer. They are meant to be used with a Yocto-Knob ( yoctopuce.com/EN/products/usb-sensors/yocto-knob ), but any electronics with GPIO, such as Raspberry PI or Arduino, would probably do as well. You will find here instructions for assembly. Details about electronics and programming can be found on our blog: yoctopuce.com/EN/article/how-to-build-an-usb-pluviometer Except for one part, this thing is assembled using screws and brass threaded inserts. This allows to assemble and disassemble it quickly and easily. Moreover, the final assembly is rock solid. Additional Hardware
You will need some non-printable hardware to build this thing.
  • One 3mm LED as powerful as possible, e.g. L-7104SEC-J3 from Kingbright
  • One 3mm photo-transistors, e.g. : SFH 310-2/3 from OSRAM
  • One 200 Ohms resistor
  • Fine electric wire
  • A Yocto-Knob or equivalent
  • A 40mm stainless pin, as fine and smooth as possible
  • M3 threaded inserts, such as BN 1036 - DIN 16903 B from bossard.com
  • M3x12 screws
  • M3x10 headless screws
  • Some glue suited for the matter used by your 3D printer (*)
    • (*) If you are using ABS, you may want to try Methyl-Ethyl-Ketone (MEK). Actually it's not glue but a powerful ABS solvent allowing to literally weld parts. Tools
  • Glue gun
  • Solder iron
    • Mounting steps
    STEP 1
    Place the threaded inserts with a solder iron in the base and the body STEP 2
    Glue the two posts on the base STEP 3
    Place the bucket, the stainless pin will act as an axle. Place the headless screws, those are meant to tune the bucket course. STEP 4
    Wire the led, the resistor and the photo-transistor. Make sure it works properly then use a glue gun for insulation, it's gonna be quitte moist in there :-) STEP 5
    Place the body STEP 6
    Place the top STEP 7
    Place funnel and the top grid. Actually those two parts are printed for the sake of having a fully 3D printed device, but a funnel from the neastest harware store would do much better as it would be smoother and non porous. Assembly is complete, now you need to write the program needed to count the bucket tilts. For more info on the programming and electronics, see yoctopuce.com/EN/article/how-to-build-an-usb-pluviometer One more thing: these parts were printed with a Dimension Elite printer. This printer features a twin head with soluble support, so we didn't have to care about hangovers. If your printer does not feature soluble support you may have difficulties to print the bucket and the funnel.

description.text:
Just a quick and very dirty bottom mounted led-block for moeller / eaton M22 industrial enclosures. I have made some of them and they are working!
WARNING: uncommented SCAD- File!

Just solder wires and resistor directly to the led and cover it with shrink tubing. then insert the led from the top and route the wire out through the side holes. It could be required to glue the led head in place with some superglue, depending of led type and printer settings.
With this thing you can add blinking, dualcolor or even rgb-leds to your professional looking and very durable eaton moeller cases.

This is just what the name says it is. A solar powered water purification cone. This idea was originally derived from "The Water Cone" (http://www.watercones.com/). I wanted to remake this and make it 3D printable. This was designed using a SolidWorks trial, which is now expired. I wanted to make some alterations to it (larger tray, looser fitting cap, a not as steep angle, make them parametric with tubing for easy farming), but to do this i will have to remake it in a free program. This item works by the choice of colors, which make it solar powered. The white, semi transparent plastic allows for light to pass through it without absorbing much of its energy. By making the tray black, it will absorb much more of the suns energy making it heat up. The hotter water in the tray will evaporate and then condense on the cooler white plastic of the cone. Once a droplet forms, it will slide down the cone into the reservoir built into the cone. After a long period of time, enough droplets will form to create some drinking water. My hope is that this design and any future derivatives of this design will provide a cheap and effective way to provide relief to those who do not have access to clean fresh water. This is a proven way to desalinate and purify water.

Printing this with PLA is the best thing to print it with because PLA does not give off chemicals like ABS does.  
For the Cone and Cap portion of this, I recommend as transparent plastic as can be used. I happened to use natural PLA which seemed to work pretty well. The cone portion of this design has a small reservoir  which collects the condensed water.  
The Tray should be printed with Black PLA(I didn't have black so I lined it with black tape).   
Once the parts are printed, fill the tray with the dirty or salty water, put the cone with the cap on it on the tray, and let it stand in the sun for a long period.  
When I tested this in a sunny area, I got about 3oz of clean water after about 8.5 hours. The temperature outside was around 75 degrees Fahrenheit.

comments.text: Great design! Do you mind explaining the process a little bit more? How is it solar-powered? Do I need any additional part for it to be solar-powered? Thanks!
comments.author: EL0630

comments.text: Great question! I updated my item description but here is how this device works. It is actually a fairly simple design. The choice of colors make this solar powered. The white, semi transparent plastic allows for light to pass through it without absorbing much of its energy. By making the tray black, it will absorb much more of the suns energy, making it heat up. The hotter water in the tray will evaporate and then condense on the cooler white plastic of the cone. Once a droplet forms, it will slide down the cone into the reservoir built into the cone. After a long period of time, enough droplets will form to create some drinking water.

I designed simplest model of holder for 8mm LED strip for planned printer upgrade.
Each holder is 100mm long. This is exactly two segments of 60 LEDs/m strip. STL file has two holders. Just slide it on steel frame of your printer. One per side or two per side by your choice.
I temporarily glued piece of strip for illustration purpose only. You can see one holder without strip and one with it. Holder can be easily moved up and down but will not fall off. I used PLA filament. UPDATE: I designed a cover for my holder. Now it looks more professionally. Carefully fit it on holder with glued LED strip. It will stay in place by design. A remix of the iphone 5 5c 5s dock that I use in my car. I haven't printed this version yet but it was really easy for me to change the dimensions to make one for the 6 and 6s. It should work just fine but if anyone wants a change to it, let me know and I'll try to accomplish it.

To add a charge cable I am using a charge cable with a fairly large connector from Anker so there is quite a bit of space for just about any cord. Just add a M3 screw with a thin hex nut to secure the cable in place. The nut provides stronger threads than just inserting it into the plastic. The dock is secured to car's center console with a strip of 3M double sided tape

title: SC8UU compatible linear bushing with M4 thread

description.text:
A SC8UU compatible linear bearing with M4 threads. No nuts required. You need a small nozzle (I used 0.3mm nozzle and 0.2mm layer height) and low layer height to be able to print the M4 thread (M4: 0.7mm pitch, 0.6mm groove depth, see photo) and the inner fins. Should the thread wear out a nut can still be conveniently used. The good bushing shape is adapted from the LM8UU shape by FlyingMashedPotatoes (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:631285) which really has some spring functionality.
  • Version 1 has a smooth running thread which might wear off easily.
  • Version 2 has a quite tight thread which will not wear but needs some force during screwing in.
  • Version 3 allows for tilting in one direction to compensate bent rods (see colorful picture).
  • A 'short' version is also made
  • A long sc8wuu version added
  • A stiffer version (for example for x-axis) was added
    • Drop a message if you encounter any problems or have suggestions. --> Why using plastic bushings instead of bearings? Less noise, tighter grip of the rods - thus less jitter and mainly elimination of rod wear. Note: Ensure that friction is very low (see post-printing) otherwise backlash may be introduced.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.3 mm Nozzle, 0.2 mm Layers

Notes: Use PLA. Not ABS. Don't use supports. Active cooling of the layers might be required. Due to the massive shaking a brim might be required to prevent ripoff of the part.

Obligatory task - Important First put in the 8mm clean (remove/clean away all lubrication!, Grinch74 suggests cleaning the rods with soap to remove all residue) smooth-rod into the bushing. You'll probably need some force. Now you have to 'burn in' the shape of the rod: Ideally use a portable electric screwdriver to rotate the rode while keeping the bushing in your hand to prevent it from rotation (don't accidentally bend the rod! see photo). In such a way the rod is heated up quickly and softens the innermost layers of the bushings which in turn adapt the round shape. Rotate it for about a minute and move it back and forth until friction does not reduce any more. Now you can remove the electric screwdriver and move the bushing back and forth by hand some time to further optimize the inner shape. Friction MUST be very low at the end otherwise the motor will skip steps or backlash will occur. PROTIP: You can even roughen the rod at the ends (by a rasp) to increase friction for burn in. Alternatively use a 8mm drill as suggested by KR2 http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:18219 Now you can lubricate the bushing and rod with silicone spray. Drop a message if you encounter any problems or have suggestions.

It depends on the Igus type. The press fit ones require to be installed as specified to reduce the play. Anyway, they comply to classes and the smooth rods must be chosen accordingly.
But indeed, to have the best match, it is better to make the bushing, mount it, ream it and break it in.

comments.text: I'm thinking about switching back to printed bushings due to the strong ringing effect on my prints due to the high play of the Igus bushings. One of the biggest problems of self made bushings is eccentricity introduced by printing or by reaming: If all 3 (or 4 ) reamed bushings of an axis are not aligned identically the carriage might be stuck. See 6th image of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1485794. I think I'll add a mark to self printed round bushings and try if it helps.

comments.text:
Thanks.
I think durability should not be a major concern because I couldn't burn-in the bushings with a smooth fast rotating rod and 3D printers do not represent high load.
However the stick-slip effect can result in vibrations during movement of the head causing ripples with a wavelength which depends on printing speed. The combination of rod and bushing material should mainly affect the magnitude of the stick-slip effect.For example IGUS suggests using Aluminum for their bushings.
STEP files are as always available in the download section.
[EDIT] Oh, I really forgot to include the STEP fort the *SC8UU_empty" version.

author: iamdonatella

description.text:
I keep my dog hydrated with this bottle carrier that doubles as a bowl.   
I designed it specifically to work with 16.9oz Poland Spring bottles - one of the more ubiquitous water bottles around in my neck of the woods.   
The paw prints keep it from rolling around when set down, but I usually hold it in my hand while using it. I included a version without the paw prints as well as a little matching cap so that people know it's the dog's bottle.   
Stay hydrated!

You can run a string (I used a shoelace) through the two holes as a shoulder strap which also helps keep the bottle in tightly. The build took 2:40 on a Replicator2 with supports and .30mm layers. Since the build uses supports, the bottom side could do with a bit of sanding.

author: jtoups

description.text: Here's a new micro-case for the Stratux ADS-B receiver. This case is designed for the recently released NooElec micro-SDRs. It won't work with the older full-length SDRs. It is built to use an MCX male to SMA female pigtail for the antenna cable. If you want to use it for a dual-band rig you will need a Y pigtail (two MCX males to one SMA female. It also has a notch for the USB cable from an external GPS. I used the GlobalSat BU-353-S4 USB GPS "mouse" - note that it requires some changes to the Stratux code at this point as the NMEA output a slightly different (shorter strings for the lat and lon values). This case does NOT support the RY835AI GPS / AHRS chip. You can read more about the decision to leave the RY835AI out here: https://www.reddit.com/r/stratux/comments/3wjdeb/new_micro_case_with_external_gps/ Let me know if you want any changes. I could add holes for the MCX male cables if you want to use the stock antennas that come with the SDRs.

Flash drive case Print both case shells, clean them up and glue them together with the flash drive circuit inside. The design is fitted for an INTENSO RAINBOW LINE drive I had laying around. If you are using a different drive, you may have to do some carving.Spacing for the circuit board is 40 x 15.8 x 4 mm.
Make sure the shells fit nicely. I used a paper binder clip to squeeze the halves together. After the glue is dry, smooth the edges and remove residues of the glue. Cryptex Slide the four Rings you chose onto the jacket. Make sure the orientation of the rings is right (compare to the picture). Add fill some glue into the notch inside of the cover and snap the jacket onto is. If it dies not fit, twist the parts around untiil they snap together. the is a little fitting key inside the notch to maintain the right orientation of the parts.

comments.author: justmey2k

comments.text:
It is a tight fit, if the printer is not very accurate. Maybe the outlines/perimeters are printed to fast or your nozzle has worn out and bigger as expected. To find your real nozzle diameter, print a little cube with no infill, no bottom layers, no top layers and only one perimeter, afterwards you measure the wall thickness. This should be the correct diameter.
However for a fast workaround just scale the rings in X and Y to 102%. To do this, import in Slc3r, mark the model and go to Object > Scale > Along X Axis and type 102%. Repeat for Y-Axis.

comments.text:
heres a better assembly walkthrough for anyone that needs it:
1) Print all files except for the ring files
2) Choose a passcode (e.g. 7926)
3) Print the ring files corresponding to those numbers (e.g. Ring7_convex, Ring9_convex, Ring2_convex, and Ring6_convex)
4) Break apart your flash drive by prying the plastic case apart (usually) I cannot provide instructions for your specific flash drive!
5) Place flash drive in case and put glue around the edge. QUICKLY place other half of case on top of the flash drive, then use a binder clip or something similar to hold the pieces together. Wipe the excess glue off with a paper towel.
More coming soon, I'm still printing the parts...

This is a prototype magnetic linear encoder board. I messed up the footprint, so the board is not functional. I'll fix this and get a v1.1 out ASAP. Gory details here: http://blog.makerbot.com/2009/11/10/monday-rd-fail/ The board itself is going to be very awesome: Sporting the Austria Microsystems AS5306 chip which is a magnetic linear encoder. You put down a strip of adhesive backed magnet and then run this chip over it. It will tell you your exact position over the strip down to 15 microns. Hawt.
DONT MAKE THIS (YET)

Six cute kitties, just trying to hang in there.  Each one is comprised of two different files - a white background layer and a black/gray/silver layer.  I printed each kitty in white and silver.  This layered process just worked out much better than a true dual extruder mixed layer process.
I glued hooks to the back of each ornament, rather than putting a hole through a poor kitty's paw.  It just looks better this way.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 1

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.25 layers

Infill:

doesn't matter

Notes: The white background layer and the black/gray top layer are each only 0.5mm thick. 0.25mm layer resolution is recommended.

Designs Each kitty file was designed by taking a photograph of a hanging kitty cat, removing the background and making it black and white only in GIMP. Then I used Inkscape to trace the outside edge (for the background white layer) and the black areas (for the black area) and saved each as a separate DXF file. The DXF files were then extruded, scaled, and centered in OpenSCAD so that they're all 100mm long and between 30-50mm wide.

This is a camera mount for an Ikea Terial lamp. It comes in 2 flavors, a 1 axis rotating mount, and a straight camera mount. I designed this to attach a webcam so I could get a top down shot of my desk while keeping out of the way.
And again, this is 1-axis (well more if you count the joint on the lamp). The ball only hinges and does not full spin. Sure it could have just been a rectangle or cylinder, but the ball just looks better.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Infill:

20

Notes: You may or may not need supports. The notable part that might need it is the ball.

ikea tertial lamp (duh)
8-32 x 3/4 screws x 2 (6-32 will work too) and nuts - connects the mount to the lamp
1/4 x 2 1/2" hex head bolt - for the tightening knob on the joint
1/4 x 1 1/4" hex head bolt - for the slotted insert into the ball. I think a 1" will work too
1/4 x 3/4" hex head bolt - if you're just using the straight mount (lamp_adapter.stl)
1/4 nuts x 2

There are 2 mods to the lamp you'll have to do.
1) remove the lamp + wires to access the mount plate. It is curved, so you'll have to use pliers to pseudo flatten it.
2) on the end of the lamp, there is a little metal c that holds the rotating rod. It has 2 notable fins that prevent the lamp from being pointed horizontally. You can either cut these fins off, or remove the metal c totally. It also prevents the lamp from 360 spinning

While modifying the lamp itself, you may be inclined to remove the little nub that prevents 360 spinning. Be warned that this also prevent the rod from sliding out.
I included the openscad file, but I didn't quite write it for full customization. Meaning there are a lot of values hard coded in and documentation is fairly lax. I did write in a 'tolerance' variable, but I make no guarantees that every dimension uses it. I tend to prefer holes to be slightly undersized so I can drill them out later.
The center ball. Has a slot to fit in a 1/4 bolt, and has a through hole to be mounted in the holder.

The connection piece for 'ball mount - holder' to the lamp. Technically you can attach the holder without it, but it adds height so the holder doesn't hit to lamp when upright. 
This piece can also be used as a straight camera mount. It has a recessed hole for a 1/4 bolt to be used as a camera mount. The counter sunk holes for the mounting screws (8-32) might be a little small depending on how your printer prints and the screws you acquire.
This is the tightening knob for the camera itself. Uses a 1/4 nut.
This is the tightening knob for the main joint. Uses a 1/4 bolt x 2 1/2" long.
The main holder for the ball. Uses a 1/4 nut on one side for the tightening knob.
A cap that fits over the extrusion on the ball. This holds the 1/4 bolt from sliding back out.
